clinical_study.brief_title: Preserving ACTs - Text Reminders to Increase Adherence to ACT Treatment
clinical_study.official_title: Preserving ACTs - Text Reminders to Increase Adherence to ACT Treatment

brief_summary.textblock:
A randomized controlled trial was conducted to assess the effectiveness of text reminders sent to ACT users through an automated text messaging system short-message-system.
Study hypothesis: text message reminders increase adherence

detailed_description.textblock: A randomized controlled trial was conducted to assess the effectiveness of text reminders sent to ACT users through an automated text messaging system short-message-system. Patients were enrolled at clinics and pharmacies upon receipt of ACTs and enrolled in the automated system for 3 days.

primary_outcome.measure: Self-reported Adherence to Artemisinin-combination Therapy (ACT) Treatment
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of participants completing full ACT treatment regimen 70 hours after treatment initiation. Subjects were visited at home, and asked to report when each of the prescribed six doses were taken. Adherence was defined as the (self-reported) completion of all six doses.

arm_group.description: Patients in the control arm only got a generic health message at the end of the study.
Patients in this arm receive six short text message reminders within 60 hours of treatment initiation at 12 hour intervals.

Patients in this arm receive six long text message reminders (reminders including justification for why patients should finish medication) within 60 hours of treatment initiation at 12 hour intervals.

intervention.description: Patients in the two treatment arms receive six short text message reminders within 60 hours of treatment initiation at 12 hour intervals to remind them to take their malaria medication as prescribed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
-subjects acquiring ACTs in Tamale, Ghana
Exclusion Criteria:
- subjects acquiring ACTs for non household members
- subjects under the age of 18
- subjects without access to cell phones
- subjects living more than 30 minutes from pickup location

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of International Health Economics

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited at all private and public facilities distributing Artemisinin-combination Therapies (ACTs).
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Only subjects from the Tamale area with cell phones were included.
